paragraphs.text: The trap of insecurity: Extrajudicial killings in Kenya.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Over the years, Kenyan police have acquired a dubious reputation of being a source of insecurity instead of one of security
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In many instances, the police represent clear, palpable and imminent danger to the lives of Kenyan citizens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The transformation of the police from a security institution into a bastion of insecurity didn't occur overnight
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: nor did it come as a surprise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it was the inevitable outcome of a number of factors
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some of these factors are beyond their control
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For instance
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: policemen are underpaid and ill-equipped to do their job
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: others seem to be an institutional choice, such as the endemic corruption within the police force
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Under the previous constitution, the police were at the beck and call of the executive
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which used it as a tool of coercion to further its political goals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a result
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when confronted by a new security situation, the executive's default response has been to set up a "special" police unit to address the situation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In most cases, t he unit would operate under minimum oversight and maximum impunity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: More than any other institution in the country, the police has deep institutional problems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: one of the most detrimental ones is its involvement in extrajudicial killings.
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Remarkably, this is not only a new phenomenon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is deeply entrenched with a clear pattern
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the 1990s, crime was on the rise in Kenya
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In order to stem the high rates of carjacking and violent robberies, in 1995 the government formed a new police unit called the Flying Squad.
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This special unit was given the express authority to shoot any suspect on sight without due process
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As a result, the unit was implicated in multiple and egregious extrajudicial killings
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which they claimed was their way of dealing with the new security reality
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In some cases, the police officers were caught shooting suspects after they had surrendered or were lying face down
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The unit executed several innocent people in cold blood
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The police command instead of seeing the unit's trigger-happy attitude as dangerous, celebrated it as the only "medicine" with which to treat spiralling crime
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The late 1980s and 1990s saw deep economic problems, shrinking political space for dissent and increasing insecurity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This was the time when criminal gangs emerged and flourished
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: These gangs e stablished their "spheres of influence"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: mostly in slum areas, where the state's presence was negligible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To establish loyalty from the community and enhance their legitimacy, these groups provided security for a token fee
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To exert their superiority, from time to time, these groups engaged each other over "territories" and business interests
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Among these groups were the Mungiki, the Taliban, the Kosovo boys, the Baghdad boys, Chinkororo, and the Kalenjin Warriors
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Mungiki is a Kikuyu word for multitude
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The organisation had both a cultural and political element to it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the beginning of the group's existence, the social aspect was more prominent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it involved traditional Kikuyu beliefs in the god named Ngai.
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as the organisation expanded, it began taking an overtly political posture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which brought them into confrontation with the state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Mungiki operated primarily in the Nairobi slums, in the Central Province and parts of the Rift Valley
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In these areas, the group started providing the poor in slum areas with protection and social services for a fee
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Refusal to pay the protection " tax " almost always resulted in violence and killings
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 2002, the Kenyan government banned 18 of these criminal gangs
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The spread of Mungiki's influence forced the government in 2007 to establish a special police unit called Kwekwe
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which was tasked primarily with hunting down members of Mungiki
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But Kwekwe's operation against the criminal group went too far
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to a National Commission on Human Rights 2008 report:"Extrajudicial executions and other brutal acts of extreme cruelty have been perpetrated by the police against so-called Mungiki adherents and that these acts may have been committed pursuant to official policy sanctioned by the political leadership, the police commissioner and top police commander"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: HRW observed in 2008 that,"The brutality of the police crackdown matched or even exceeded that of the Mungiki itself."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Kenya has been in the crosshairs of the transnational jihadi movement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the past, the fact that Kenya was seen as being firmly in the western sphere of influence made Kenya a target , with most of the incidents, including the 1998 US embassy attack, targeting western interests
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: after Kenya's intervention in Somalia in 2011, the country itself become a target
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Terrorism activity in Kenya reached a peak with the attack on the Westgate shopping mall in September 2013
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: unidentified gunmen killed 67 people and injured almost 200 others
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As a response to the growing terrorism threat, the Kenyan government created the Anti-Terrorism Police Unit (ATPU) in March 2003, following the 2002 attack on an Israeli-owned Mombasa hotel
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This was also accompanied by the passage of Anti-Terrorism Act in 2012
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As part of the wider counterterrorism effort, the government also began a huge crackdo wn on the Somali and Muslim communities especially in Nairobi, parts of Northern Kenya and coastal Kenya
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the crackdown intensified, a number of extrajudicial killings of Muslim preachers took place, some in the coastal city of Mombasa
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Most of the victims were suspected of having connections with Somalia's al-Shabab group
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: in almost all the cases the police deny culpability
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: research by human rights organisations reveals the ATPU's involvement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In its August 2014 report,"Kenya: Killings, disappearance by anti-terror police," HRW points to" ...evidence of at least 10 cases of extrajudicial killings of terrorism suspects, some of whom were last seen in ATPU custody or had been threatened by the unit's officers after courts had released them"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The Kenyan government has accused some of the clerics who were killed of recruiting Muslim youth for terrorism activities through their mosques
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: despite initiating investigations against them, the government never followed through to prosecute the imams
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: After public outcry over the killing of Muslim cleric Ibrahim "Rogo" Omar, the government set up a task force to investigate his murder
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The director of public prosecution promised in 2013 that he will institute an inquest, but has not done so yet
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: One of the commissions established following the 2007-2008 violence to look at the role of the police, was the Waki Commission
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Established to look into the circumstances and facts surrounding the violence and provide recommendations, the Waki Commission found that of the 1,500 deaths, the police was responsible for more than 30 percent of them
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: As a result several reform measures were proposed including the establishment of a civilian oversight of the police, and many other reforms
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: due to lack of political will, the police reforms have stalled
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The extrajudicial killings by the police in Kenya are anchored in a systemic lack of accountability and deeply entrenched culture of pervasive impunity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the police undoubtedly face ever changing security challenges
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: its involvement in extrajudicial killings make matters worse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Effective security sector reform is the only way forward
paragraphs.label: assumption
